title: Precise Measurements of Spatial Coherence and Brightness for Thermionic and Field-Emission Guns
content: Partial spatial coherence of electron beams imposes limitations in various imaging/diffraction methods in electron microscopes, especially those utilize the wave nature of electrons such as off-axis electron holography, high-resolution TEM/STEM, and electron diffractive imaging. Therefore, quantitative estimation of the beam coherence is one of the important issues for the correct interpretation and enhanced quality of the experimental data in those methods. In the present study, we have developed a method to precisely measure spatial coherence in electron beams based on analysis of the Airy diffraction pattern from a selected-area (SA) aperture [1]. Although the spatial coherence is generally measured from the visibility of the interference fringes formed by an electron biprism, the present method can be conducted without biprism in most of existing analytical TEMs if equipped with a post-column energy filter to enhance the camera length.
